model.hed: The 7 Things You Might Be Doing Wrong to Your Pasta
model.promoHed: The 7 Things You Might Be Doing Wrong to Your Pasta
model.seoTitle: The 7 Things You Might Be Doing Wrong to Your Pasta
model.seoDescription: Troubleshooting pasta problems like reheating pasta, using pasta water, and the right pastas for the right sauces.
model.socialTitle: The 7 Things You Might Be Doing Wrong to Your Pasta
model.socialDescription: Common problems with pasta and how to troubleshoot them.
model.body:
Overcooking the noodles. Adding too much salt to an acidic tomato sauce. When it comes to butchering a pot of pasta, these are given. But what about the little tipping points that can make the whole dish sink? With a little consulting from the kitchen team, here’s a few of the most common errors you might be making to your pasta. 

####Mismatching Pastas with Sauce####
This is like wearing stripes with plaid. Short shapes are great for chunky sauces, because they allow bits of vegetables and meat to nestle into cavities. Long stringy pastas, like linguine or fettuccine, are best with delicate creamy sauces. Denser pastas with more bite, like rigatoni or ziti, are best with hearty meat sauces. The exception to everything is [bolognese](http://www.epicurious.com/ingredients/when-use-fresh-pasta-versus-dry-pasta-article).

####Under/Over Seasoning The Pasta Water####
It takes more than a pinch and less than a mountain of salt to cook a pound of pasta. When getting the boiling water ready, taste it. It should taste noticeably and pleasantly salty, but not like the ocean.

[#recipe: /recipes/54a4238c19925f464b3798b2]||||||

####Adding oil to the water#####
It seems to make sense, right? Have a couple of drops of olive oil on top of the pasta water to add flavor, right? “This is a huge no-no,” says Fox. Adding oil makes the pasta greasy and prone to slipperiness—not good if you want your sauce to stick. But as with any rule, there are exceptions. "If I cook my pasta ahead of time, then I do toss the pasta with oil to help keep it from sticking together," says Food Editor Katherine Sacks.

[#recipe: /recipes/55d4e07b54b469aa41d146da]|||
Pasta with Swordfish and Cherry Tomato Sauce
|||

####Your Reheating Is Just Wrecking Havoc####
Once you’ve strained the pasta, it’s almost imperative to start saucing immediately. But what about the next day? "Pasta, at its best, does not reheat well,” says Fox. Just sticking pasta into the microwave renders it into a gummy mess. So change the approach for a whole new dish. Food Editor Anna Stockwell loves frying leftover spaghetti in tomato sauce with olive oil. Wait until it’s crisp, then top it with an egg for brunch. You can also bake leftover pasta. Sacks keeps leftovers from getting too brittle by [baking them with lots of milk](http://www.epicurious.com/recipes/food/views/baked-penne-with-farmhouse-cheddar-and-leeks-351513) or cream. [THIS SEEMS LIKE A SEPARATE TOPIC THAN JUST OVERALL TIPS ON PASTA COOKING. WANT TO REPLACE WITH A TIP ABOUT DRAINING YOUR PASTA AT THE RIGHT TIME? YOU REALLY NEED TO TASTE IT 4-5 TIMES TO NAIL THE MAGIC WINDOW]

####Rinsing the pasta! With Cold Water!####
Even if you are trying to shock the pasta from cooking any further, using cold water to rinse pasta is not a good idea. It’s very difficult to reheat the noodles after rinsing them in cold water. Strain it hot, sauce it hot, and serve it hot.

####Using way too much sauce####
If you put all of the effort into making your own pasta, you want to taste that, too, and a flavorful sauce will knock out the flavor. ”The pasta should be nicely coated with sauce,” says Food Editor Mindy Fox, “but not swimming in it. So what’s the perfect pasta-to-sauce ratio? Chef Sara Jenkins of NYC's [Porchetta](http://www.porchettanyc.com/about.html) shared the perfect amount with Fox. "After you've eaten the pasta, there should be just enough sauce left in the bowl to swipe a small piece of crusty bread through," says Fox. And that's a very edible way to estimate.

[#recipe: /recipes/54a41eed6529d92b2c0074e5]||||||

####Not Saving Your Pasta Water####
That now-cloudy water you cooked your pasta is now a magical elixir—don’t you dare dump it! Save ½ to ¾ cup of the starchy water for later use. It makes a great binder for your pasta sauce or can work to thin an overly thick cream or butter sauce.

inline.hed: Rigatoni with Spicy Calabrese-Style Pork Ragù
inline.promoHed: Rigatoni with Spicy Calabrese-Style Pork Ragù
inline.socialTitle: Rigatoni with Spicy Calabrese-Style Pork Ragù
inline.socialDescription: Rigatoni with Spicy Calabrese-Style Pork Ragù
inline.dek: Any short, tubular pasta will work with this meaty ragù. We used sedanini ("little celery") on the cover, but easier-to-find rigatoni and penne are great, too.
inline.promoDek: Any short, tubular pasta will work with this meaty ragù. We used sedanini ("little celery") on the cover, but easier-to-find rigatoni and penne are great, too.

inline.dek:
Maybe you're not a
nonna. And you didn't
inherit a faded recipe for
lasagna Bolognese from
one, either. Not to worry.
What matters is that this
version of the Italian
classic tastes as though
it's been perfected over
generations. The dish's
complex sauce, rich
béchamel, andhere's
the secreteight
impossibly thin pasta
layers (yes, homemade)
create a brilliantly balanced bite. Time and
dedication to each and
every element turn this
recipe into one that  your 
grandkids (and friends)
will be begging for.
